intro: Mentha serratula, commonly known as serrated mint, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, serrated leaves that are often aromatic when crushed. Its flowers are small, tubular, and arranged in whorled clusters, usually blooming in late summer. Mentha serratula is known for its medicinal properties and has been used traditionally for digestive and respiratory ailments.
